pluck.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to pull something quickly in order to remove it
pluck.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He plucked a couple of plastic bags from the roll.
Reaching up, she plucked an apple off the tree.
pluck.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to take someone away from a place or situation that is dangerous or unpleasant in a quick and unexpected way
pluck.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She was plucked from obscurity  (=made suddenly famous) by a Hollywood film producer.
Three survivors were plucked to safety after being in the sea for 7 hours.
Some refugee children were plucked out of the country in a number of mercy missions.
pluck.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to pull the feathers off a dead chicken or other bird before cooking it
pluck.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to pull the strings of a musical instrument
pluck.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Someone was plucking at the strings of an old guitar.
pluck.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: It takes a lot of pluck to stand up to a bully.
